abstract: Ocean acidification (OA) resulting from increasing atmospheric CO strongly influences marine ecosystems, particularly in the polar ocean due to greater CO 2 solubility. Here, we grew the Antarctic sea ice diatom Nitzschia sp. ICE-H in a semicontinuous culture under low (~400 ppm) and high (1000 ppm) CO 2 levels. Elevated CO 2 resulted in a stimulated physiological response including increased growth rates, chlorophyll a contents, and nitrogen and phosphorus uptake rates. Furthermore, high CO 2 enhanced cellular particulate organic carbon production rates, indicating a greater shift from inorganic to organic carbon. However, the cultures grown in high CO conditions exhibited a decrease in both extracellular and intracellular carbonic anhydrase activity, suggesting that the carbon concentrating mechanisms of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H may be suppressed by elevated CO. Our results revealed that OA would be beneficial to the survival of this sea ice diatom strain, with broad implications for global carbon cycles in the future ocean.

ICE-H may be suppressed by elevated CO. Our results revealed that OA would be beneficial to the survival of this sea ice diatom strain, with broad implications for global carbon cycles in the future ocean.

body_text.text: Atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) has increased by nearly 40% over the past 260 years, from pre-industrial levels of 285 parts per million (ppm) in 1750 (IPCC, 2013) to > 400 ppm in 2016 (https:// www.co2.earth/). The surface ocean has absorbed approximately onethird of anthropogenic CO 2 emissions (Sabine et al., 2004) , which has led to a shift in seawater chemistry by reducing the pH, carbonate ion concentration, and calcium carbonate saturation of seawater, so-called ocean acidification (OA) (Orr et al., 2005; Doney et al., 2009; Feely et al., 2009) . By the end of the 21st century, atmospheric CO 2 levels could reach approximately~1000 ppm (Friedlingstein et al., 2006) . OA directly affects marine calcifying organisms, such as planktonic coccolithophores, molluscs, echinoderms, and corals (Riebesell et al., 2000; Anthony et al., 2008; Appelhans et al., 2012) ; photosynthetic organisms, such as green algae, red algae, diatoms, cyanobacteria and dinoflagellates (Xia and Gao, 2005; Fu et al., 2010; Xu et al., 2010; Ihnken et al., 2011) ; and some marine fish (Munday et al., 2009) . In addition, OA likely affects the biogeochemical dynamics of organic carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus in the ocean as well as the trace elements (Doney et al., 2009; Millero et al., 2009) . These effects can result in significant changes in the structure and function of marine ecosystems. Subsequently, these changes will exert both positive and negative feedback on atmospheric CO 2 levels.

Southern Ocean ecosystems, which are particularly susceptible to OA, are canaries in the coal mine for global changes (Somero, 2012) . The changes in CO 3 2concentrations and aragonite or calcite saturation states due to OA will be faster in polar regions than in other regions. All Southern Ocean surface waters are projected to become undersaturated with respect to aragonite by 2100 (Orr et al., 2005; Mcclintock et al., 2009 ). Because OA is believed to have the largest impacts on the aragonite saturation in the Southern Ocean, it is essential to investigate the consequence of elevated CO 2 levels on marine organisms in the Antarctic regions. Recent predictions of the impact of OA in high latitude regions have primarily focused on calcifying organisms such as pteropods, mussels and oysters (Orr et al., 2005; Doney et al., 2009) ; however, the reports concentrating on sea ice microalgae are still few. Antarctic sea ice microalgae play a fundamental role in polar ecosystems, contributing approximately 5%-25% to the total annual primary production in ice-covered regions and providing an important food resource to grazers such as copepods, krill and salp (Lizotte, 2001) . Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a better understanding of the effects of OA on the sea ice microalgae. Diatoms carry out > 40% of the global ocean primary productivity (Nelson et al., 1995; Roberts et al., 2007) , which also are the prominent components of the sea ice algal community in the Southern Ocean (Thomas and Dieckmann, 2002; Ryan et al., 2011) , Previous studies have examined the physiological responses of diatoms to OA. These conflicting findings indicate high species specificity regarding the impacts of OA on diatoms (Gao and Campbell, 2014) . Some researchers determined that diatoms, including some sea ice diatoms (Mitchell and Beardall, 1996; Tortell et al., 2008) , exhibit carbon concentrating mechanisms (CCM), which are regulated by inorganic carbon (Raven et al., 2011; Reinfelder, 2011) . However, the CCM of diatoms differ among diatom species and remain somewhat controversial (Burkhardt et al., 2001) , particularly the precise CCM in the sea ice diatom Nitzschia remain unclear.

Although some studies of sea ice diatoms have concentrated on the growth and photosynthetic responses to OA (Boelen et al., 2011; Torstensson et al., 2013; Torstensson et al., 2015) , few studies have focused on the effects of OA on diatoms in terms of carbon cycling and the correlation between physiological performance and organic carbon production. As the biological carbon pump, the responses to OA are associated with global carbon cycling. The links between the properties of the biological responses and organic carbon production are essential to fully comprehending the feedbacks associated with Antarctic marine organisms under OA to ocean carbon cycling. Under this scenario, we investigated the effects of OA on the physiological performance, inorganic nutrient uptake and carbon fixation of the Antarctic sea ice diatom Nitzschia sp. ICE-H. Here, we emphasized the particulate organic carbon production to predict the effects of OA on carbon cycling. Additionally, the CA activity in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H was also characterized to predict the CCM of this sea ice diatom. This study will ultimately help us to understand the responses of Antarctic organisms to future environments.

Stock and experimental cultures of the Antarctic sea ice microalgae Nitzschia sp. ICE-H were isolated from floating ice near the Zhongshan Research Station of Antarctica (S 69°48′, E 77°48′). The cultures were maintained in an illuminating incubator (HP-400GE, Ruihua, Wuhan, China). The algae were grown in sterilized f/2 medium prepared from 0.22 μm filtered seawater (Guillard and Ryther, 1962; Guillard, 1975) , with a diurnal cycle of 12 h:12 h light:dark (L:D) and a light intensity of 40 μmol photos m − 2 s − 1 at 4 ± 1°C.

Two levels of CO 2 were implemented: low (LC,~400 ppm) and high (HC, 1000 ppm) CO 2 levels. The cultures (1800 ml) were grown in 3000-ml Erlenmeyer flask with a sterilized cotton plug to prevent contaminant. The independent cultures were equilibrated at the two target CO 2 levels by constant bubbling at a uniform flow rate of 400 ml min − 1 , which was automatically manipulated by a CO enrichment device (CE100C-6, Ruihua, Wuhan, China). The device utilized a mixture of filtered outdoor ambient air and pure CO 2 (Gattuso and Lavigne, 2009) , and the variation of the CO 2 concentration was < 5%. The CO concentration of ambient air was measured with an infrared CO 2 analyzer Lincoln, NE, USA) . To maintain a stable carbonate system, the experiments were run utilizing identical semicontinuous culturing methods, diluting the cultures based on the cell concentrations with freshly sterilized and pre-CO -equilibrated medium. Prior to being used for dilution, the medium was adjusted to the experimental temperature and corresponding CO 2 levels. The dilution volumes were adjusted to maintain the cultures at the initial cell concentrations. The other culture conditions (light and temperature) were the same as those mentioned above. The experiments were run for 30 days. After acclimation to the target carbonate chemistry system for 9 days, the cells grew exponentially in all treatments; the experimental samples were subsequently taken at the same time (9.00 a.m.) every 3 days. Three replicate experiments were randomly assigned to each treatment.

The carbonate system was verified in all experiments by measuring the pH and dissolved inorganic carbon (DIC) before and after the dilution (Dickson et al., 2007) . The pH and salinity were measured using a pH meter (Seven Compact S210, Mettler-Toledo, Switzerland) and a salt meter (YK-31SA, Lutron, Taiwan, China), respectively. DIC was measured using an acid-sparging instrument that was modified from a developed device. One milliliter of samples was filtered through a Whatman GF/F filter (0.7 μm) and then injected into a syringe without any CO 2 exchange, where the samples were acidified using phosphoric acid. The released CO 2 was then quantified with an infrared CO 2 analyzer Lincoln, NE, USA) . The precision of the instrument was 2.5%. The other parameters in the carbonate system, such as CO 2 , HCO 3 − , CO 3 2and A T (total alkalinity), were calculated using CO2SYS software (Lewis and Wallace, 1998) .

Chlorophyll a (chl a) were measured on a chlorophyll fluorometer (Design 10, Turner, Trilogy) using the acidification method. Samples (50 ml) were filtered onto cellulose acetate membranes. The filters were enfolded with aluminum foil and then frozen at − 20°C until analysis. Chl a was extracted in 10 ml of 90% acetone for 24 h in the dark at 4°C and then measured using the fluorometer.
body_text.section: Growth rates, chlorophyll a and chlorophyll fluorescence measurements

body_text.text: A pulse-amplitude-modulated (PAM) fluorometer monitoring system (Phyto-PAM, Walz, Germany) was used to determine the chlorophyll fluorescence parameters (Schreiber, 2004) . Prior to the fluorescence measurements, the samples were dark acclimated for 15 min. The PSII effective quantum yield (Ф PSII ) was calculated as (F m ′ − F) / F m ′, where F m ′ and F represent the instant maximum and steady-state fluorescence, respectively. The relative electron transport rate (rETR) was calculated as Ф PSII × PAR × 0.5, where PAR is the photosynthetic actinic radiation, and 0.5 is the factor that assumes that half of the absorbed light is distributed to PSII. The light utilization efficiency (α) was automatically obtained from the rapid light response curve (LRC).

The CA activity of algal cells was determined as described by Wilbur and Anderson (1948) , with some modifications. The assay was performed at 4°C. The algal cells were collected and resuspended in 8 ml of 20 mM ice-cold Veronal buffer (pH = 8.3). Seawater without algal cells was used as the controls. The reaction was initiated by injecting 4 ml of ice-cold CO -saturated water. The enzyme activity was determined by monitoring the time required for the pH of the assay solution to decrease from 8.3 to 7.3. The CA activity was calculated from the following formula:
= × − Enzyme unit (EU) 10 (T /T 1)
where T 0 and T represent the times required for the pH to decrease from 8.3 to 7.3 in the controls and enzyme catalyzed reaction, respectively.

The algal cells were disrupted by an ultrasonic homogenizer at 4°C to measure the total CA activity (CA T ) as described above. The CA activity in intact cells indicated the extracellular CA activity (CA ex ), and the broken cells indicated the CA T , including both extracellular and intracellular CA (CA in ).

Levene's test was used to evaluate the homogeneity of variance. The mean values were compared with analysis of one-way ANOVA. Significant differences between the treatments were determined using Tukey's HSD test for data with homogenous variances and Tamhane's T2 test or Dunnett's T3 test for nonparametric data. All statistical analyses were performed using SPSS 13.0 software.

The carbonate parameter values before and after the dilution at both CO 2 levels exhibited no obvious changes during the whole culture period ( Table 1) . The average pH under the high and low CO (HC and LC) levels was 8.061 ± 0.058 and 7.514 ± 0.017 (n = 45), respectively, and the average DIC was 2184.1 ± 42.7 and 2375.6 ± 40.5 μmol kg − 1 (n = 45), respectively. Elevated CO 2 significantly increased the DIC, HCO and CO 2 in the medium (P < 0.001), representing a 8.8%, 10.6% and 284.2%, respectively, increase compared with the LC treatments, and significantly decreased the pH and CO 3 2by 7.3% (0.55 units) and 220.9% (P < 0.001), respectively. The total alkalinity (A T ) changed slightly under HC and LC, with average values of 2336.6 ± 46.8 and 2350.1 ± 39.7 μmol kg − 1 (n = 45), respectively.

After acclimation to the target carbonate chemistry system for 9 days, the cells grew exponentially in all treatments ( Fig. 1a and b) . The cell concentration of HC treatment was higher than that of LC treatment from the 9th day until the end of the experiment. The mean HC cell concentration of (56.4 ± 4.7) × 10 4 cell ml − 1 was significantly higher than the LC cell concentration of (50.8 ± 4.2) × 10 cell ml − 1 (P = 0.024). The specific growth rates fluctuated from 0.217 day − 1 to 0.290 day − 1 in LC and from 0.240 day − 1 to 0.340 day − 1 in HC. The growth rates of both the LC and HC treatments exhibited a similar trend, slightly decreasing from the 9th day until the end of the experiments. The growth rate was enhanced by the elevated CO 2 ; moreover, the mean growth rates increased significantly in HC compared to that in LC by13.7% (P = 0.031).
body_text.section: Growth rates and chlorophyll a contents

body_text.text: The chlorophyll a (chl a) contents of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H before and after the dilution in each treatment were monitored throughout the incubation period (Fig. 1c) . After the first 9 days, the cells grown under HC conditions displayed higher chl a contents by 4.9%-20.5% than those grown under LC conditions, but the differences were not significant (P > 0.05). Although the cell concentrations in both treatments after the dilution remained stable and changed little throughout the incubation period (Fig. 1a) , the mean chl a contents in HC (0.063 ± 0.008 pg cell − 1 ) were significantly higher than that in LC (0.049 ± 0.007 pg cell − 1 ) from day 9 on (P = 0.004), suggesting that the elevated CO 2 level increased the chl a accumulation in individual cells of this diatom strain.

body_text.text: The photosynthetic parameters, including the effective quantum yield (Ф PSII ), relative electron transport rate (rETR) and light utilization efficiency (α) were measured (Fig. 2) . The average Ф PSII of HC was 0.58, which was significantly higher than that in LC (P = 0.008), with a value of 0.56. The values of rETR in HC were slightly higher than that in LC, and no significant interaction was detected between HC and LC (P > 0.05). The α values of the two treatments changed slightly, with average values of 0.15.

The nitrogen (N; nitrate, nitrite and ammonium) and phosphorus (P; phosphate) uptake rates of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H grown under different conditions were determined (Fig. 3) . Nitzschia sp. ICE-H grown under high CO 2 levels had faster N and P uptake rates than those grown under low CO 2 levels from the 12th day onward. Moreover, when integrated over 24 days, elevated CO significantly affected the average N uptake rates (P = 0.005) and P uptake rates (P = 0.017), representing a 25.2% and 25.0% increase compared to those in LC. These results indicate that high CO 2 contributed significantly to N and P uptake.

The cellular particulate organic carbon (POC) content and POC production is shown in Fig. 4 . The POC content in HC was slightly higher than that in LC throughout the entire experiment, although no significant difference was detected (P > 0.05). The average cellular POC in HC was 7.4% higher than that in LC. POC production in HC was significantly higher than in LC (P = 0.005). The average POC production in HC during the whole period was 22.6% higher than that in LC.

The carbonic anhydrase (CA) activity in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H varied with the CO 2 concentration (Fig. 5) . The total carbonic anhydrase (CA T ) in LC was 3.74 ± 0.59 EU (10 8 cell) − 1 , which was 1.8 times greater than the values in HC of 2.01 ± 0.40 EU (10 8 cell) − 1 . The extracellular (CA ex ) and intracellular (CA in ) carbonic anhydrase activity in LC was 205.8% and 165.5% higher than that in HC. In addition, the CA ex activity was slightly lower than the CA in activity in both treatments.

Southern Ocean take up more than approximately 20% of the global ocean CO 2 uptake (Takahashi et al., 2002) , which will help moderate future climate change. Many Antarctic organisms, unicellular algae in particular, are susceptible to global changes (Somero, 2012) . However, there is currently little information on the effects of CO 2 on microalgae in extreme environments. Hence, we examined the effects of OA on the physiological performance of the Antarctic sea ice diatom, Nitzschia sp. ICE-H, which is linked with nutrient uptake and carbon fixation. Particular attention was paid to analysis of the effects on carbon sequestration and transformation under high CO 2 conditions. As we demonstrated here by partially renewing the culture medium, the biological activity did not perturb the carbonate chemistry of the media, and the changes in pH and DIC of the culture were minimal (Table 1) . Changes in growth reflect the adaptability to the future ocean environment to some extent. In this study, the cell concentrations and specific growth rates increased under high CO 2 conditions (1000 ppm) in comparison with cultures exposed to ambient (~400 ppm) CO 2 levels, which are characteristic responses of enhanced metabolic activity of this diatom species in response to increased CO . This capability of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H may indicate that this species is capable of successful future adaptation to OA if these organisms respond in a similar fashion in future long-term experiments. Similarly, several recent studies observed that the growth of some diatoms, such as Thalassiosira pseudonana, Skeletonema costatum, Navicula pelliculosa and other diatom species (Kim et al., 2006; Tortell et al., 2008; Low-Décarie et al., 2011; Mccarthy et al., 2012) , tended to increase under high CO 2 conditions (750-1000 ppm). Elevated CO can increase the N and P assimilation in cells, which was observed in our study. Enhanced N and P assimilation could be responsible for the observed increase in cellular particulate organic N and P. Moreover, the cellular chl a concentrations reported here were significantly enhanced by increasing CO , which may also explain the observed increase in algal growth.

However, these stimulated responses are not universal (Gao and Campbell, 2014) . In contrast to the above results, other studies found that the growth of some sea ice diatom responded negatively to elevated CO 2 (McMinn et al., 2014) . For instance, the growth rates of Nitzschia directa were reduced by approximately 5% under high CO 2 conditions (960 ppm) (Torstensson et al., 2013) . Additionally, the growth of some sea ice diatoms, such as Chaetoceros brevis, showed little or no change (Boelen et al., 2011) . This discrepancy might be attributed to differences in the diatom taxa. Obviously, the responses of diatoms to OA are quite variable, and not all diatoms benefit from elevated CO 2 .

Within the diatoms studied to date, simulated and insignificant photosynthetic responses to high CO 2 conditions were similarly observed (Gao et al., 2012; Yang and Gao, 2012) . This study clearly demonstrated that elevated CO 2 supported the PSII activity of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H. The effective quantum yield (Ф PSII ) reflects the photosynthetic activity of algae. The values of Ф PSII in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H were in the range 0.55-0.59 ( Fig. 2a) , which were higher than the values (0.20-0.51) from sea ice algal community in Antarctica (McMinn et al., 2003) , indicated normal functioning, although both of them were lower than the maximal values from other aquatic plants (Kolber et al., 1988; Schreiber et al., 1995) . The Ф PSII was significantly increased by elevated CO 2 when integrated over 24 days, reflecting an increase in photosynthetic efficiency, which partly explains the mechanism of the positive effect of OA on growth. The Ф PSII is also used as an indicator of the influence of external stress on phytoplankton photosynthesis. The algae may decrease Ф PSII to maintain an effective photosynthetic reaction under environmental stress. The stress of salt, nutrient limitation and low light (Wang et al., 2010; Ryan et al., 2011; Li et al., 2012) probably induced the depressed of the Ф PSII . The higher values of the Ф PSII under elevated CO 2 conditions implied a high level of acclimation to the high CO 2 . The photosynthetic parameters across CO concentrations might be associated with the cellular chl a concentrations, which were increased under high CO conditions. The main increased photosynthetic pigment would then be available for capturing more light energy for photosynthesis.

Furthermore, photosynthesis in diatoms is often driven by visible light. The photosynthetic acclimation of diatoms to OA became more evident under high or low light conditions. For instance, elevated CO 2 reduced the photosynthesis of diatoms under high light (Gao et al., 2012) . Conversely, the stimulation was observed under low light (Li and Campbell, 2013) . Therefore, the differential responses showed species-specific mechanisms in coping with the combined impacts of OA and light. Especially in polar oceans due to the annual expansion and melting of sea ice and the seasonal alternation in solar irradiance, there were light factors to influence the photosynthetic performance in sea ice diatom, so the photoperiod and light intensity associated with OA should be considered together in future research.

Carbonic anhydrase (CA), which is a zinc-containing enzyme that can convert accumulated HCO 3 to CO 2 and concentrate CO 2 around the site of carbon fixation, plays a key role in photosynthetic CO 2 fixation. Evidence for the presence of CA gene and activity has been found in some of the marine diatoms (Hopkinson et al., 2013; Tanaka et al., 2016) . This study clearly demonstrated that CA was present in both intracellular and extracellular forms in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H (Fig. 5) .
body_text.section: Effects of ocean acidification on carbonic anhydrase

body_text.text: The cultures grown in high CO 2 conditions resulted in a decrease in CA activity, which indicated that CA was sensitive to CO and inhibited by elevated CO 2 . This finding is consistent with the report of Burkhardt et al. (2001) , who suggested that the CA activity in diatoms was inversely related to CO 2 concentration. However, the CA activity did not affect by the inorganic carbon utilization, which relied on more diffusive CO 2 entry. The presence of CA ex indicated that CA ex promoted CO 2 into the cell by accelerating HCO to CO 2 (Hopkinson et al., 2011; Ihnken et al., 2011) . The decline in CA ex activity under high CO 2 conditions suggested that the CA ex activity could be induced by the change in the environmental CO 2 concentration (Elzenga et al., 2000) . A possible reason for less CA ex being produced was that more available CO resulted in less HCO 3 needed for conversion to CO (Giordano et al., 2005; Matsuda et al., 2011) . This observation is consistent with the suggestions of various studies (Hofmann et al., 2013) . Previous studies have indicated that the CA ex activity in Phaeodactylum tricornutum was even close to the detection limit under high CO levels (Burkhardt et al., 2001) . The decrease in CA in activity under high CO 2 conditions suggested that CO 2 concentrations also regulate the CA in activity. The physiological function of CA is an important component of the CCM (Hopkinson et al., 2011; Hopkinson et al., 2016) . The CCM provide a steady-state CO 2 concentration at the active site of ribulose-1,5biphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (Rubisco) by CA when inorganic carbon is limiting, which is energetically costly (Roberts et al., 2007; Raven et al., 2008; Spalding, 2008; Reinfelder, 2011) . The response of diatom growth and photosynthesis to changes in the CO 2 supply is determined by the mechanism of inorganic carbon uptake. In addition, an increased diatom growth rate under high CO 2 conditions could be attributed to the saving energy by the partial repression of CCM to some extent (Raven, 1991) . The major energy expended by the CCM in diatoms is the active transport of HCO 3 into the chloroplast (Hopkinson et al., 2011; Hopkinson et al., 2016) . Thus, high ambient CO in the medium could result in a reduction of the energetic cost of carbon fixation. Hence, OA saves energy through CCM down-regulation in marine diatoms due to increased CO entry. Accordingly, it indicated that the decrease in CA activity may be associated with the down-regulation of CCM. However, our results are insufficient to explain the CCM of sea ice diatom, it requires a comprehensive assessment of the CA activity, inhibitory effect of CA, half saturation constants for DICdependent O 2 evolution, CA gene expression and so on. Therefore, the role of CA and its association with the CCM in the sea ice Nitzschia needs to be further explored.
body_text.section: Effects of ocean acidification on carbonic anhydrase

body_text.text: As mentioned previously, the physiological responses to OA in diatoms tend to be very species specific; all the effects would have great ecological and biogeochemical consequences, especially on carbon cycling. The individual response in cellular POC of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H to high CO 2 was positive. The greater carbon fixation in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H due to elevated CO 2 was directly verified by this observation, which could also explain why higher photosynthetic productivity and higher nutrient uptake rates were observed under higher CO conditions.
body_text.section: Organic carbon production under ocean acidification

body_text.text: In this study, the POC production rates were sensitive to the external CO 2 level. The increase in POC production under high CO 2 conditions suggested that Nitzschia sp. ICE-H shifted more biogenic carbon flow from inorganic to organic forms under OA conditions. The increase in organic carbon also revealed the contribution to carbon acquisition of the photosynthetic carbon supply by OA. POC leads to carbon export to the deep ocean when it is associated with sinking diatom particles, and can be remineralized and returned the atmospheric carbon pool. In addition, some POC could be transformed into dissolved organic carbon (DOC) by bacteria; thereby, more POC contributes to more DOC production. Conversely, organic carbon production had the opposite effect on the CO 2 partial pressure in seawater. Enhanced POC production in Nitzschia reduced the CO 2 in the surrounding medium. Therefore, the increase in organic carbon production in sea ice diatoms due to the increase in CO 2 has the potential to significantly modify the carbon in the oceans. If the observed responses of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H to elevated CO 2 are a general phenomenon in most diatoms, the increase in POC production could significantly change the structure and functioning of sea ice ecosystems, in which diatoms play a dominant role.
body_text.section: Organic carbon production under ocean acidification

body_text.text: Our observations of increased growth rates and organic carbon production by Nitzschia sp. ICE-H under high CO conditions suggest that there is a greater possibility of blooms of this species with projected future trends of atmospheric CO enrichment. In the ocean environment, biogenic carbon fixed by diatoms is transformed through the food web. The pivotal organism in the Southern Ocean is krill, which feed largely on diatoms in winter, while bacteria are fueled by the dissolved organic matter produced by diatoms (Thomas and Dieckmann, 2002) . Therefore, the ocean's capacity to sequester carbon through the biological pump may be positively correlated to atmospheric CO 2 concentrations. Higher algal growth rates would not only enhance the vertical carbon flux but also increase the remineralization depth. The increasing output by the biological pump would ultimately affect the vertical distribution of inorganic nutrients in the ocean, transferring nutrients from the surface to the deep ocean. Overall, OA can influence biological carbon recycling in the Southern Ocean and regulate the air-sea CO 2 flux. All these processes, in turn, may create potential climate feedbacks.

Apart from OA, increasing atmospheric CO 2 will be inextricable linked to other changes, including higher surface temperature, higher light irradiation, lower salinity and enhanced stratification. Although the interaction between future CO and some climate changes has been reported previously for some diatoms (Harada et al., 2005; Torstensson et al., 2013; Tew et al., 2014; Jazwiecki and Grimaldi, 2015) , the coupling effects are still largely unknown; moreover, the results depend even more on biotic factors, such as the taxonomic groups, life history, population abundance and nutrient status, and abiotic factors, such as the concentrations of CO 2 and duration of experiments. Global climate change is occurring in the Southern Ocean, and polar microalgae will have to survive multiple environmental changes in the future. Based on the above discussion, the combination of stressors on sea ice algae at high latitudes that accompany OA need to be further considered.

Atmospheric CO 2 has been increasing since the Industrial Revolution. OA as a result of increasing atmospheric CO 2 greatly influences marine ecosystems. OA affected many metabolic processes in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H, including growth, photosynthesis, carbon fixation, and inorganic nutrient uptake. Elevated CO induced a stimulated physiological response in Nitzschia sp. ICE-H. The cultures grown in high CO 2 conditions experienced a decrease in both the extracellular and intracellular carbonic anhydrase activity, suggesting that the carbon concentrating mechanisms of Nitzschia sp. ICE-H may be down regulated by elevated CO 2 . However, inorganic carbon utilization was not affected, based on the higher level of cellular particulate organic carbon. In addition, high CO significantly enhanced particulate organic carbon production, indicating a greater shift from inorganic to organic carbon. These results suggest that Nitzschia sp. ICE-H under high CO 2 conditions can substantially influence carbon recycling in the marine environment. Moreover, our results revealed that OA may be beneficial to the survival of this diatom strain, Nitzschia sp. ICE-H, in extreme environments, with broad implications for global carbon cycles in the future ocean. This study contributes to an understanding of how sea ice microalgae respond to OA at high latitudes and provides basic data on the mechanisms of the effects of OA on sea ice diatoms.
